description: From Middle English unnoble, equivalent to un- +â€Ž noble.

adjectives.description: unnoble (comparative more unnoble, superlative most unnoble)

entries.meaning: (dated, chiefly pre 1900) Not of noble rank.
examples: Yet from the commencement of mining there have been unnoble proprietors of mines, who belonged to the class of merchants.

entries.meaning: (metallurgy) Of a metal, being at the lower end of the electrochemical series, i.e. oxidising readily.

verbs.description: unnoble (third-person singular simple present unnobles, present participle unnobling, simple past and past participle unnobled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (someone or something) no longer noble
